text: We'll hear argument next in No. 90-1150, Donald J. Willy v. Coastal Corporation.
Thank you Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Did you just refer, Mr. Maness, to one of our cases in saying that it was controlled by that case?
Yes, sir.
What case was that?
United States Catholic Conference against Abortion Rights Mobilization, Incorporated.
And when was... do you have a citation for that or what?
Yes, Your Honor, I do.
Okay.
Catholic Conference was a 1988 decision of this Court.
Beatty.
Except for, except for the Catholic Conference of Bishops case.
What we had in Catholic Conference was a situation in which the bishops did exactly what Mr. Willy could have done.
So you would draw the line between standing on your rights and refusing to proceed further and that cannot be the subject of a sanction.
--Certainly.
Instead of a hypothetical, what about this very case?
Well, the short answer, Your Honor, is that he can behave.
Well, of course.
--I'm sorry, perhaps I didn't understand your fact situation.
Right.

--and he simply refused to respond, then what would happen is a judgment would be entered against him and he would then have the opportunity to appeal the lack of subject matter jurisdiction to the Fifth Circuit.
Oh, I see.
Certainly he litigates the jurisdictional issue because it's even conceded by petitioner that the Federal court has the jurisdiction to determine jurisdiction.
Well, but did he do any more than contest the jurisdictional issue in this case?
Certainly, Your Honor.
Let me just be sure I get the procedure.
No.
--Oh, right.
I hope and I would submit that that's not a hard, that shouldn't be that difficult a choice for a litigant to take.
Well, it's a little different choice, though, than the choice of the subpoenaed party in the Catholic Bishops case.
Yes.
Well, our, our cases in Chambers against NASCO and Hutto against Finney suggests that fee shifting sanctions are analogous to civil contempt.
If I might, Your Honor, address both that issue of Hutto v. Finney as well as the issue of attorney fee shifting.
I don't think they help you because there there was article III jurisdiction at one point in those cases.
I don't raise it for that position.
But your argument on punishment, I'm not sure he disagrees with, with the distinction he emphasized from United Mine Workers between civil and criminal.
But... I understand that.

Mr. Chief Justice, the Court stated in Catholic Conference that a court, Federal district court's subpoena power under Federal Civil Rule 45 cannot be greater than its article III subject matter jurisdiction.
Thank you, Mr. Maness.
